dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Really interesting point from Eliza Forsythe at the University of Illinois—she says we aren't in the normal dynamic, and people who want to leave their jobs aren't waiting.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Really interesting point from Eliza Forsythe at the University of Illinois-she says we aren't in the normal dynamic, and people who want to leave their jobs aren't waiting.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: We arent in the normal dynamic, says Eliza Forsythe, a professor at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, who has studied the pandemic labor market. At this point, it doesnt look like people who want to leave their jobs are waiting.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and that's backed up by the data, right? The voluntary quit rate actually recovered as early as September last year, which is way sooner than in past recessions.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and that's backed up by the data, right? The voluntary quit rate actually recovered as early as September last year, which is way sooner than in past recessions.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Especially unusual is the rate at which employees are voluntarily quitting their jobs recovered in September.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. And it's not just white-collar jobs either—hospitality and service industries are seeing this too, even though they've been hit hard by health risks.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. And it's not just white-collar jobs either-hospitality and service industries are seeing this too, even though they've been hit hard by health risks.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Combine that with pent-up demand from workers whose job searches were put on hold due to the pandemic, and from employers who have struggled to fill white collar and service jobs alike, and it would seem natural to assume that the floodgates will soon open.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: But here's the thing—unemployment numbers don't tell the whole story. The Federal Reserve says five million people have left the job market entirely since the pandemic started.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But here's the thing-unemployment numbers don't tell the whole story. The Federal Reserve says five million people have left the job market entirely since the pandemic started.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The five million Americans who have left the job market altogether since the start of the pandemic, according to the Federal Reserve, are not counted in that figure.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Right, and a lot of those are women, especially mothers. There are 1.4 million fewer moms in the workforce now than in early 2020.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, and a lot of those are women, especially mothers. There are one point four million fewer moms in the workforce now than in early twenty twenty.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: while there are now 1.4 million fewer mothers in the workforce than there were in early 2020.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Which is huge. And then you've got people totally switching career paths—law school apps up 20%, med school up 18%.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which is huge. And then you've got people totally switching career paths-law school apps up twenty percent, med school up eighteen percent.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Applications to law and medical school have jumped by 20% and 18% respectively, a sign that many are reconsidering career paths, while there are now 1.4 million fewer mothers in the workforce than there were in early 2020.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: So employers who think they can wait to address retention are already behind, like the article says.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So employers who think they can wait to address retention are already behind, like the article says.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: For sure. And some companies are getting creative—Microsoft and Salesforce going hybrid permanently, Dropbox letting people work from home indefinitely.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: For sure. And some companies are getting creative-Microsoft and Salesforce going hybrid permanently, Dropbox letting people work from home indefinitely.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Microsoft and Salesforce, for example, are adopting permanent hybrid work models, while others like Dropbox, Twitter and Shopify will let their employees work from home indefinitely.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Even Walmart's paying out billions in bonuses to hourly workers. That's a smart move when replacing someone can cost twice their salary.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Even Walmart's paying out billions in bonuses to hourly workers. That's a smart move when replacing someone can cost twice their salary.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In December, Walmart announced that it would pay its 1.5 million retail workers another $700 million in cash bonuses, contributing to a yearly total of $2.8 billion. When the cost of replacing an employee can amount to twice their annual salary, a one-time bonus could be a critical long-term investment.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, Paul McDonald from Robert Half mentioned that stuff like childcare help or extra leave can be a huge differentiator for talent.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, Paul McDonald from Robert Half mentioned that stuff like childcare help or extra leave can be a huge differentiator for talent.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Childcare assistance, additional maternity or paternity leave, or subsidized tutoring can [also] be a huge differentiator for the employers offering them.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: It's like the whole playbook for keeping employees has been rewritten in the past year and a half.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's like the whole playbook for keeping employees has been rewritten in the past year and a half.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Absolutely. And even though some people thought unemployment benefits were keeping folks home, analysts are pushing back on that—saying the effect is pretty minimal.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Absolutely. And even though some people thought unemployment benefits were keeping folks home, analysts are pushing back on that-saying the effect is pretty minimal.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Unemployment insurance, with its elevated pandemic bonuses, has been offered as an explanation by policymakers and economists, though some analysts have pushed back, arguing that its effect on returning to work is minimal.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: So really, it's this mix of health concerns, reprioritization, and just… pent-up demand to make a change.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So really, it's this mix of health concerns, reprioritization, and just... pent-up demand to make a change.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Makes you wonder if high turnover is just the new normal, huh?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Makes you wonder if high turnover is just the new normal, huh?

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Could be. Either way, companies that adapt fast are gonna come out ahead.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Could be. Either way, companies that adapt fast are gonna come out ahead.

artist_script:
Really interesting point from Eliza Forsythe at the University of Illinois—she says we aren’t in the normal dynamic, and people who want to leave their jobs aren’t waiting.
HostB: Yeah, and that’s backed up by the data, right? The voluntary quit rate actually recovered as early as September last year, which is way sooner than in past recessions.
HostA: Exactly. And it’s not just white-collar jobs either—hospitality and service industries are seeing this too, even though they’ve been hit hard by health risks.
HostB: But here’s the thing—unemployment numbers don’t tell the whole story. The Federal Reserve says five million people have left the job market entirely since the pandemic started.
HostA: Right, and a lot of those are women, especially mothers. There are 1.4 million fewer moms in the workforce now than in early 2020.
HostB: Which is huge. And then you’ve got people totally switching career paths—law school apps up 20%, med school up 18%.
HostA: So employers who think they can wait to address retention are already behind, like the article says.
HostB: For sure. And some companies are getting creative—Microsoft and Salesforce going hybrid permanently, Dropbox letting people work from home indefinitely.
HostA: Even Walmart’s paying out billions in bonuses to hourly workers. That’s a smart move when replacing someone can cost twice their salary.
HostB: Yeah, Paul McDonald from Robert Half mentioned that stuff like childcare help or extra leave can be a huge differentiator for talent.
HostA: It’s like the whole playbook for keeping employees has been rewritten in the past year and a half.
HostB: Absolutely. And even though some people thought unemployment benefits were keeping folks home, analysts are pushing back on that—saying the effect is pretty minimal.
HostA: So really, it’s this mix of health concerns, reprioritization, and just… pent-up demand to make a change.
HostB: Makes you wonder if high turnover is just the new normal, huh?
HostA: Could be. Either way, companies that adapt fast are gonna come out ahead.
